Award.AwardTitle: Microscale Swimming Medibot in Human Body Propelled by Oscillating Bubbles

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Microscale Swimming Medibot in Human Body Propelled by Oscillating Bubbles


The objective of this research is to develop a microscale medibot (medical robot) of 20~150 ?√ùm in size, which can swim inside the human body. The approach is to utilize the recently discovered propelling phenomena occurring in oscillating microbubbles.

Intellectual Merit: The proposed research will generate an understanding and knowledge of propulsion physics and mechanisms, develop a system-level medibot device, and apply the device to a model application. Additional intellectual merits are: (i) The use of microbubbles inside the human body is clinically proven as microbubbles are currently injected into the blood vessels and used as ultrasound contrast agents; (ii) Seeded medibots in the body can be easily propelled and located by existing ultrasound imaging systems; (iii) Medibots are powered wirelessly, not requiring any physical wiring; and (iv) The propulsion system is very simple, making device fabrication much easier.

Broader Impact: The proposed medibot can be used for navigating through low-speed blood vessels and quiescent fluid-filled regions, providing direct access to extremely hard-to-reach spots in the human body that would not be realized by using currently existing interventional robots. This capability has tremendous impact on various potential biomedical applications, possibly opening a new horizon in drug delivery, bio-sensing, and bio-surgery. This research will also have significant impact on education by re-engineering interdisciplinary coursework for both undergraduates and graduates; having graduates and undergraduates involved in research especially from the underrepresented groups; demonstrating results from this project in local K-12 schools or community museums; and improving infrastructure for training in interdisciplinary micro-science/engineering.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project developed an underwater microswimmers that can navigate microfluidic environments and possibly narrow passages in human bodies to perform bio sensing, drug delivery, imaging, and microsurgery. The microswimmer is propelled by a gaseous bubble trapped in a suspended microchannel and oscillated by an external acoustic excitation. The propelling swimmer is designed and microfabricated out of parylene in micro scale (equivalent diameter of the cylindrical bubble is around 60 mm) using microphotolithography. The propelling mechanism is studied and verified by computational fluid dynamics (CFD) simulations as well as experiments. The acoustically excited and thus periodically oscillating bubble generates alternating flows of intake and discharge through an opening of the microchannel. As the amplitude and the frequency of oscillating flow increase, the difference between intake and discharge flows becomes significant enough to generate a net flow (microstreaming flow) and a propulsion force. Propelling motions by a single bubble as well as an array of bubbles are achieved and demonstrated in a centimeter scale pool (beyond chip level scale), which is a similar scale to in vivo applications.

Using multiple bubbles, bi-directional (linear and rotational) propelling and 2-D steering motions are achieved. The key idea in these propelling is the bubble oscillation and thus propelling force are highly dependent on the frequency of the acoustic wave and the bubble length. This dependence is experimentally studied by measuring resonance behaviors of testing pool and bubble using a laser Doppler vibrometer (LDV) and by evaluating generated streaming flows. Multiple bubbles with different length are mounted on a microswimmer with a variety of arrangements. By controlling the frequency of acoustic wave, only frequency-matched bubbles can strongly oscillate and generate strong propulsion. By arranging multiple bubbles of different length in parallel but with their openings opposite and by switching the frequency of the acoustic wave, bi-directionally linear propelling motions are successfully achieved. For bi-directional rotations, the similar method but with diagonal arrangement of bubbles on a rectangular swimmer is also applied. The rotation can be easily reversed when the frequency of the acoustic wave is switched.  For 2-D steering, short bubbles are aligned perpendicular to long bubbles. It is successfully demonstrated that the microswimmer navigates through a T-junction channel under a full control with and without carrying a payload. During the navigation, the frequency is the main control input to select and resonate targeted bubbles. All these operations are made by a single piezoelectric actuator as the acoustic excitation input.

Throughout this project, two PhD graduates have been produced, who have published numerous Journal and conference papers. In particular, one of them took this project as a full PhD thesis work. The other student is currently working in industry in USA based on his training through this project. In addition, an underrepresented undergraduate has participated in this project as Summer Research Program and continues her career in a similar area. The produced scientific results have been used for many class subjects (e.g., fluid mechanics courses, Microfabrication and microfluidics course, etc.) that stimulate students to have cognition in the microfluidic world. The developed experimental setup and infrastructure and computational tools are currently being used for the continued projects in the lab. 

 


Last Modified: 02/22/2016
Modified by: Sung K Cho

Image
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: This project developed an underwater microswimmers that can navigate microfluidic environments and possibly narrow passages in human bodies to perform bio sensing, drug delivery, imaging, and microsurgery. The microswimmer is propelled by a gaseous bubble trapped in a suspended microchannel and oscillated by an external acoustic excitation. The propelling swimmer is designed and microfabricated out of parylene in micro scale (equivalent diameter of the cylindrical bubble is around 60 mm) using microphotolithography. The propelling mechanism is studied and verified by computational fluid dynamics (CFD) simulations as well as experiments. The acoustically excited and thus periodically oscillating bubble generates alternating flows of intake and discharge through an opening of the microchannel. As the amplitude and the frequency of oscillating flow increase, the difference between intake and discharge flows becomes significant enough to generate a net flow (microstreaming flow) and a propulsion force. Propelling motions by a single bubble as well as an array of bubbles are achieved and demonstrated in a centimeter scale pool (beyond chip level scale), which is a similar scale to in vivo applications. Using multiple bubbles, bi-directional (linear and rotational) propelling and 2-D steering motions are achieved. The key idea in these propelling is the bubble oscillation and thus propelling force are highly dependent on the frequency of the acoustic wave and the bubble length. This dependence is experimentally studied by measuring resonance behaviors of testing pool and bubble using a laser Doppler vibrometer (LDV) and by evaluating generated streaming flows. Multiple bubbles with different length are mounted on a microswimmer with a variety of arrangements. It is successfully demonstrated that the microswimmer navigates through a T-junction channel under a full control with and without carrying a payload. During the navigation, the frequency is the main control input to select and resonate targeted bubbles. All these operations are made by a single piezoelectric actuator as the acoustic excitation input. Throughout this project, two PhD graduates have been produced, who have published numerous Journal and conference papers. In particular, one of them took this project as a full PhD thesis work. The other student is currently working in industry in USA based on his training through this project. In addition, an underrepresented undergraduate has participated in this project as Summer Research Program and continues her career in a similar area. The produced scientific results have been used for many class subjects (e.g., fluid mechanics courses, Microfabrication and microfluidics course, etc.) that stimulate students to have cognition in the microfluidic world.
